sp.p: (quickly) That, I also can undertake to say she is ; and even more, wonderfully beautiful!

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: You speak with extraordinary certainty for one who has never seen the lady !

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I have seen her portrait, (with a slight, bitterness) I beg your pardon ! I did not readily appreciate the point of your remark, (to Lady SloWburn) You see on what grounds Constance will found these distressing suspicions of hers?

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: I must tell you candidly, Arthur, I don't think you are entirely blameless. There has latterly been a good deal that has appeared like concealment in your conduct.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I own I have a secret trouble preying on my mind—a trouble this very portrait, of which I have told you, has revived.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Oh!—it has awaked unpleasant recollections?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Bitter ones, believe me.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: This is too much! (she throws herself into a chair and weeps.)

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: You forget, Arthur, that your mother suffered deeply on account of your father's inconstancy ; that she died, perhaps earlier than she might, had she not had cause to suspect that he had given to another the affection which was hers of right. Do not bring upon my child this inheritance of misery ! (points to Constance.)

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (going to her tenderly) My love! my love! what is all this ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (softened by his voice) Nothing ; no, nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p:
Constance, when I can tell you the secret of my care, you shall judge whether I have not just cause for all I do and suffer. To-day we have friends and
acquaintances about us; let us at least hide our troubles from their eyes.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: I won't be troubled any more—I'm not troubled!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Thanks, dear ! Believe me, if the secret had been mine alone I should already have imparted it to you. I am going to dress. (exit D.R.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (following him with her eyes) He's deceiving me, mamma ! I know he's deceiving me !
sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Gibbs, D.R.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (aside) They are still here! (aloud) Know my place, I hope I do, my lady ; but if I might make so bold—

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (sharply) What do you want, Mrs. Gibbs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (rather embarrassed) Which a little while ago I heard my lord a-mentioning a painter —

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Leastways, begging your ladyship's pardon— two painters it was as he spoke of.

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: What is it you want to know, Mrs. Gibbs ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (more at ease with Lady Slowburn) Which it is my daughter, as your ladyship has often kindly heard me say, deserted me to go and marry a painter, when, though her mother says it, with such a figure as hers ——

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: What was the name of the painter your daughter married ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Never would the ungrateful girl let me know, or long ago I would have found him out! Shut her up on purpose to prevent her lawful mother setting eyes on her again, is what I do believe that man is now a-doing ! If your ladyship would be so kind as to ask the painters as is coming here to dinner, telling 'em as that my daughter was well-be known at eighteen-pence an hour—Henrietta being her Christian name, and a complexion like a bouquet— perhaps I might find out where she is now a-living.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (aside to Lady SloWburn) Good heavens, mamma ! what if this should be

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: Impossible! a daughter of Mrs. Gibbs! your suspicions are really making you unreasonable, (aloud) Leave us, Mrs. Gibbs. We'll make some enquiries for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: My duty to your ladyship, and begging to remind you that whatever is her married name, Henrietta I had her christened, six weeks and one day after she were born—smiling like a image.
sp.stage: Enter Servant, D. L.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: (at D. L.) Mr. Edgeworth and Mr. Maguilp, your ladyship. (exit Servant.
sp.stage: Enter Edgeworth and Maguilp, D. L.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (aside) The two painters !—If I can only find an opportunity, speak to them I will myself.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: May I beg you to excuse Lord Midford for not being present to receive you ?

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Oh ! I'm sure, pray don't think of apologising.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: The fact is, he stayed so late in town.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: At my house, then, I fear it must have been.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (aside) This is Mr. Edgeworth! (aloud) I must not be surprised at his having forgotten the hour in your house, Mr. Edgeworth ; no doubt there is so much that is beautiful to be seen there !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Your ladyship overrates the few finished studies—

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: But you have some wonderful portraits— one, at all events have you not ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) Her husband has told her !

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (aside to Lady S.) Take Mr. Maguilp away, mamma, (aloud) I only know that Lord Midford returned home, quite enthusiastic in his praises of it. I have now greater hopes than over of your succeeding with my beautiful ancestress, Diana Slowburn. (to Maguilp) We have a few pictures worth seeing,—would you not like to examine them ?

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Ah, madam !— (bowing profoundly)-— the beauties of art pale before those—of—of —

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Mamma, show Mr. Maguilp our gallery.

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (bowing to Lady S) Most happy—I'm sure. (aside) How deucedly odd !

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: (aside) I must humour her—or she'll be commiting some act of folly ! (aloud—taking Maguilp's arm) I shall be delighted to have your opinion. (exit with Maguilp, D. L.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: We can now speak freely.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Lord Midford tells me that you are quite resolved to carry out your idea of having a complete series of the ladies of your family.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (motioning him to take a seat, they both sit) Yes. As to the men, I leave them to be treated in any way that you and my husband may decide on ; I only take my ancestresses under my protection. For them, one and all, I demand—faces of absolute beauty!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: One and all ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Without exception ; that of the Lady Diana being made supreme—something lifted above the beauty we meet with in ordinary life—ideal and yet human ! It seems to me that, if I were a painter, such a type of beauty would always be present in my mind.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Indeed, madam ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: The painter's highest ideal of beauty must —I imagine— always be the woman he loves ; and if, in the present day, he fails to produce on his canvas such lovely creatures as the Fornarina of Raphael, and the Joconda of Leonardo da Vinci, it is because he lacks the courage of the great Italian painters, who gloried in exhibiting to the world the objects of their adoration.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: It may be that he prefers the sancity of his passion to public admiration of its object.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: But his fame as a painter ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Would be too dearly won by such a sacrifice. (rising) Oh, madam ! think !—you ask of him, to expose to the public gaze the idol of his heart; to give up to criticism, disdain, or cold admiration, that which he loves with all the fervour of his soul! No, no, madam ; what you ask is a sacrilege ; it would be to throw open his holy of holies to the coarse curiosity of the rabble !

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (aside) He's jealous! (aloud) Will you forgive me, Mr. Edgeworth—for what may have seemed like an attempt to penetrate a secret

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: A secret, madam ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: One which Lord Midford would never forgive me for having spoken of to you.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Lord Midford ! Excuse me, madam,—but, has his lordship spoken to you on the subject of this secret?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Without intending to do so.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) Dora turned deadly pale on hearing Lord Midlord's name—and he was visibly affected on seeing her portrait!

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Pray let us talk of something else.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: One word more, madam—and forgive me if I speak too freely. From what, you have said, I am sure that you have become acquainted with the fact of my life being darkened by a shadow of mystery. I am sure it cannot be—mere idle curiosity that prompts you to probe my secret, at the risk of wounding

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: A heart already bleeding with jealousy !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Madam! who told you ? ——

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: My own heart, Mr. Edgeworth—that suffers equally with yours.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Oh, madam ! is it possible you believe ——

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: No,—nothing, Mr. Edgeworth. I—I'm very sorry I spoke.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You have said too much, madam, not to say more. Has Lord Midford ever spoken to you of—of Mrs. Edgeworth ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: We are both getting out of our depths, Mr. Edgeworth. Whatever my husband's past life may have been—he is not accountable for it to me.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: But Dora—my wife—is accountable to me for hers!

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Dora ?—that is not the name I imagined.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Slowburn,D. L.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Oh! that is very likely : it is not her proper name.

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: My love, I want you.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: I'll come, mamma, (aside) I was right! (aloud) After dinner, we may have an opportunity for continuing this conversation Excuse me for leaving you. (she and Lady Slowburn reach D. L., when they are met by Mbs. Gibbs.)
sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Gibbs, D. L.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Begging pardon, my lady—but if you could tell me whether him it is ?

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: You had better question him yourself.
sp.stage: (exit with Constance, D. L.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: I must have an immediate explanation with Lord Midford I cannot—will not—rest till I have satisfied my doubts, (is going towards D. L., when he is stopped by Mrs. Gibbs.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (placing herself before him) Begging your pardon, sir, which my name is—Gibbs !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (smiling) I'm sure I've no intention to dispute the fact, Mrs. Gibbs. But what of the undisputed fact?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (taking a more imposing attitude) What of it? Begging your pardon, sir, once more—I am Mrs. Gibbs !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: I take your word for it, ma'am ; but

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Little would it signify, sir, if you didn't; for there is born ladies in this house, and servants—as their words was never doubted—in one of the best of families of Cornwall—which, though not my native place of birth, is where I lived and met with my misfortune, a year ago it is —

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Cornwall ? a year ago ? Tell me clearly, if you can, my good woman, what you mean.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: G. My daughter, sir?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (looking more closely at her) Your daughter, ma'am ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Ungrateful that she was, I will say! and her with a figure as, painted in iles or water, any nobleman in the land would have been proud to hang in his drawring room!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You say you were living in Cornwall twelve months ago ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Well you may say that!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (looking intently at her) It's impossible !

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (whimpering) Which more hard-hearted than ever I supposed, you are, to say so ! But though you may deny her lawful mother, I hope you'll never make my poor misguided child unhappy—after marrying her as you have done !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) Dora this woman's daughter !

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Nothing you can have to say against my Henrietta—whatever have been her ingratitude to me as brought her into the world

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Henrietta! your daughter's name is Henrietta?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: As there is parish books to prove, whenever my word—which is her own mother's—is not sufficient to be took alone!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: My good woman

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Tell me first that my ungratiful child is well in her health.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) There is only one way to get rid of her. (aloud, looking through D. L.) The gentleman now coming —Mr. Maguilp—will very likely be able to tell you all you want to know about your daughter, (aside) How shall I be able to find Lord Midford alone ? (exit, D.R.
sp.stage: Enter Maguilp, D. L.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Well, more astonished I never was—to think that, after all, it wasn't him ! But now I know his name— and here he is !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Where's Edgeworth, I wonder ? Another elderly female ! I seem to gravitate towards all the elderly women in this house—or they towards me !

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (placing herself before him) My name is Gibbs —Mr. Maggles!

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (starting) Eh ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (in an imposing attitude) Gibbs—Mr. Maggles!

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (aside) By all that's unpromising—my motherin-law !

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Which that my name have took your speech away, is what does not surprise me !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (aside) If I can only keep her off for four- and-twenty hours—time to get into fresh lodgings, or go abroad ! (aloud) I think they are sitting down to dinner— good day, Mrs. Gibbs ! (going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (resolutely barring his way) No, Mr. Maggles! after searching for you as I have done for twelve months, escape me you shall not now !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Escape ! Can you think it possible I thought of such a thing ? after enjoying the unexpected pleasure of meeting you in the midst of such agreeable associations? Nothing of the sort, I assure you! (trying to get away) Good day!

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (not to be moved) Less I might have felt her ingratitude if she had only written me one line !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: She thought, perhaps, that you might not have been able to —

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Which I hope you will allow me to say, Mr. Maggie's, that always it have been my fortune to live in the midst of persons as could have read anything as she had chose to write to her own lawful mother, however ill she might have used her otherwise !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: That difficulty might have been got over, as you say, no doubt; but, as it accidentally happened that writing was overlooked in your daughter's education

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: My daughter's education, Mr. Maggies—what- ever you may think of it—is what it is! But what, as her own mother, I can say is—that with such a figure as hers

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: I beg your pardon for interrupting you, but I'm sure they are sitting down to dinner!

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: My daughter, Mr. Maggles

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: You shall see her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Deceiving me you are not, Mr. Maggles? When shall I see my ungrateful child ? Name the day.

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Say this day ten years—I mean, this day week. (going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (staying him) Forgive her I never can ! But, has she—have you—any ——

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: One ! Good evening ! (going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (staying him) A grandmother, and not even to know it! Boy or girl, Mr. Maggles ?

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Boy—I mean, girl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Bless it! I always said my Henrietta —

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (escaping) Thank you—yes! Good evening! (runs out, D.R.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Stop! Mr. Maggies! (hurrying after him) I forgot to ask him whether the little darling was like — (exit, D. R,
sp.stage: Enter Lord Midford, with Merriton, a letter in his hand, D. L.

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: I've just received this note, and want you to hear the contents without delay, (opening the letter.)

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: It relates to pressing business, then?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: (reading the letter) Singularly so. "The bearer of this note has discovered who Mrs. Edgeworth is, and wishes to confide this knowledge to Mr. Merriton. As the intimate friend of Lord Midford, Mr. Merriton will be glad to receive the intelligence referred to, which is in the highest degree important to his lordship. It is, above all, essential that Mr.Merriton should at once receive from the bearer certain explanations which cannot be made in writing."

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: What answer have you given ?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: None, yet; your servant is waiting outside to deliver it when it's ready. I prefer that the "explanation" here spoken of should be made directly to you.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: To me ?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: My dear Lord Midford, I was honoured by your father's friendship—may I speak out ?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: My dear Merriton—of all things, I wish you would.

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: Here goes, then! If I am not enormously deceived, Lady Midford is already jealous.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Merriton!

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: I knew it could not be done! and it's exactly because I do not wish to be mixed up in an impossible manner in an affair—at the bottom of which there is plainly a lady—I have read you this letter instead of answering it without consulting you.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: My dear Merriton, you shall shortly hear how groundless are your suspicions, (rings.)

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: With all my heart. In the mean time, mind what you are about. (exit, D. R.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (to SeRvant, who enters at D. L.) Show the person in who brought a note to Mr. Merriton. (exit Servant, D. L.) Highly as I esteem Merriton, I, too, prefer to deal single-handed with this mysterious confidence.
sp.stage: Enter Servant, showing in Redway, D. L.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The gentleman who brought the note, my lord. (exit, D. L.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (aside) Rashleigh's companion ! (aloud) You did not expect to —

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: To find myself in the presence of Lord Midford, instead of Mr. Merriton? No, my lord ; but I wrote to Mr. Merriton in the expectation that he would show you my note.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: The hour of your visit is somewhat inconveniently chosen, but if you will make your communication, whatever it is

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Very briefly, my lord ; but first—I know I may rely on your lordship's word—you must promise me that if you should not think fit to agree to the terms I am about to propose to you—

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (surprised) Terms !

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Give me your promise of secrecy, my lord, and I will explain.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I promise.

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: As the price of the secret I have to confide, I demand ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: What have you to give me for so large a sum?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Something worth fifty thousand pounds to Lady Midford, and fifty thousand more to another member of your family, possibly. You see I do not ask a large price.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Pray explain yourself more clearly.

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: (dropping his voice) The will made by Lady Belfield is in existence.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: The will!

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: And I know where it is to be found !

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: The girl who was accused of killing Lady Belfield did not destroy it, then?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: The poor girl you speak of was as innocent as yon are, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Innocent! oh ! are you sure of that ?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: As certain as that I am now standing in your lordship's presence.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p:
(greatly excited) Grace! Oh, man—if you can
but prove what you have now told me, I will make your fortune!

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Thanks, my lord. I trust entirely to your lordship's word. On the strength of what I can tell, Grace Holden may be able to prove her own innocence.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (astonished) Then she still lives ?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Have you not already guessed, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Mrs. Edgeworth ——

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Is Grace Holden.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (aside) My instinct did not mislead me, then ! as I looked upon her portrait—it was my father's face I saw in hers ! (aloud) You are sure - quite sure—not of her innocence, of that I have now no doubt—but that you will be able to prove it ?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: That her innocence may be established, I have no doubt. The first thing we have to do is to secure the will.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: It is not in your possession, then?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: No, it is in the hands of a Jew ; but it is to be had for the money, for which it is held as security; only, my lord, there is not a moment to be lost in getting it into your possession. A certain project of Mr. Philip Rashleigh's makes delay dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: A project of Philip Rashleigh's ?

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: My lord, he has determined on having an interview with Mrs. Edgeworth, even if he has to force his way into her presence.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: But be does not know her.

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Nor does she know him ; but he is bent on finding out the secret of her seclusion, and if he discovers who she is—he is not the man to stick at destroying her to secure his own safety.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: His own safety !

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: It was with his connivance that Holden undertook to steal the will, and deliver it into my hands.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: You, then

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Yes, I was the tool of Philip Rashlsigh and the Jew with whom he is heavily in debt; and he has broken the bargain he made for my services.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Only save Mrs. Edgeworth, and I will more than keep my promise to you !

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: One thing more, my lord. Besides giving me the ten thousand pounds for the will, you must promise to let me have twelve hours to get out of the country, before the magistrates have anything to do with the affair.
sp.stage: Enter Edgeworth, D. L.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) Not alone !

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I give you my word.

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: Come with me at once, then, my lord. Rashleigh may even now, be with Mrs. Edgeworth.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I'm perfectly ready to follow you. (going) Edgeworth!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord—I wish to have a moment's conversation with you—to ask you a question.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Quickly, then, my dear Edgeworth.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: My wife—the portrait I showed you to-day—do you know her ?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You confess?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Confess !—Ah ! I understand you ; but, believe me, your suspicion wrongs both your wife and me. At this moment she is in danger, Edgeworth—Philip Rashleigh ——

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Rashleigh!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Hasten home, without a moment's delay, my dear Edgeworth, and protect your wife from the insults of that heartless scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: My wife in danger of insult from Philip Rashleigh! He, too, is known to her! Forgive me, Lord Midford ; I have greatly wronged you by a suspicion ; but l am grievously entangled in a constantly-expanding net of mystery.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: My dear Edgeworth, lose not a moment in reaching your home ! (he wrings his hand, and Edgeworth rushes out, D. L.)

sp.speaker: Redway.
sp.p: And for us time flies, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Come, then. (going
sp.stage: Enter Constance and Lady Slowburn, D. L.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Good heavens, Arthur! are we to sit down to dinner to-day or not ?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: My love, you must apologise for me ; an affair of vital importance calls me to town ngain.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Arthur!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: I am very sorry, dear, but I must go. (to Redway) Come this way. (exit with Redway, who bows to the ladies, D. R.)

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (bursting into tears) I am sure of it! I am sure of it, mamma ; he's deceiving me!
sp.stage: Enter Maguilp, closely followed by Mrs. Gibbs, D. L.

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Really, if dinner is to be delayed much longer, I fear I may be driven to nibble the furniture !

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Maggles! waiting for this opportunity I have been, to ask you whether my granddaughter —bless her little heart!—is like

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: Like?—oh, yes, enormously ! You wouldn't know her whiskers one from the other! Good evening! (rushes out D. R.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G.
sp.p: (following him) Which, if not already christened, Mr. Waggles, nothing there is as I should so much wish as that her name should be — (exit after him, D. R.

div.head: Scene Second.—
div.stage: A drawing-room in Edgeworth's house. Elegantly furnished. Fire-place, R., large window, L. through which the moonlight streams into the room. Door L., another door, F. L. C. A table, R. C, with handsome lamp burning on it. Between the table and the fire-place a, sofa. Among the ornaments of the room, a trophy of curious arms conspicuously hung on one of the walls. The room only partially lighted.
Grace discovered seated on the sofa; she is pale and agitated.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I am lost! I am lost; In this monster's power, every moment of my life will be filled with terror worse than death. Uncertain whether my unhappy father lives or dies, I dare not give this wretch up to justice !—but he who has no scruples, whenever his own safety demands it, will denounce me ! No, no ; I cannot endure the thought of my miserable past being laid bare to Cyril's eyes ! Torn from his roof, he would drive me from his heart! Better a thousand times, that I should fly, no matter where, so that it be far, far away from all who may now recognise me and bring the dreadful truth to his knowledge ! Let me not hesitate. My jewels will buy me food, (rising, and suddenly pausing) My jewels ? Oh, no! they are his — everything, even to the dress I now wear, is Cyril's ! It would be robbery. But, if I beg my bread, I may be seized as a vagrant, questioned—my secret wrung from me ! Oh, heaven ! am I entirely helpless ? is there no way I can turn for relief from the great misery a father's sin has brought upon me ? no way but death ? I see none ! I see none! for I have not strength to battle longer with my fate. Forgive me, heaven!—forgive me, Cyril! (she rushes to the trophy, and seizes a small stiletto.)
sp.stage: Enter Susan, quickly, D. L. C.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Ma'am ——

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (retreating towards the sofa) What, what is it, Susan ? (she sinks down upon sofa and conceals the stiletto under one of the cushions — aside) Heaven's interposition!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You spoke of going to bed early, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I—I have not made up my mind. My headache is better, and I may sit up until your master returns.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Master will most likely be late, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You are right; and, perhaps I had better not wait, (aside) And yet, if I do not sit up for him, he will think that I am ill, and question me ! I know not what to do! (aloud) Leave me, Susan, and when your master returns I—I wish you not to tell him that anyone has called since he has been out.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! very well, ma'am, (aside) Well!—and he said he came from master, too ! (exit D. L. C.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Good heavens ! what will this girl think !—and when Cyril returns, how shall I be able to hide my sufferings from him ? He will see that I am pale and trembling! and to-morrow, and to-morrow, it will be the same ! No ! I cannot bear such a life of torment! Let me die at once and end it! (she is about to seize the stiletto but pauses) Lost wretch that I am, I dare not! I am afraid either to live or to die ! Cyril! (she again hides the stiletto.(
sp.stage: Enter Edgeworth, D. L.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (speaking as he enters without seeing Grace) It is true, then! he has dared !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (starting to her feet) No, Cyril, no one ! (sinking back upon the sofa, partly insensible.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (going to her) Fainted ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (after a pause without opening her eyes) No, Cyril, no !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Is her mind wandering ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Have pity on me, Cyril! (opening her eyes) Ah! where am I ? Is it you, Cyril ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Yes, it is I.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I've had a frightful dream!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: A dream ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes—I dreamt that you were driving me from your house!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: On what account ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Because I do not know—I forget.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (fiercely) Because you had infamously deceived me !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (starting to her feet) Oh, Cyril! what have I said in my sleep or my delirium ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: There has been no need for me to play the spy !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Philip Rashleigh ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: No, it was not Philip Rashleigh who told me that you had received his visit while I was out, but the whole household !—your neighbour, your servant, are full of the scandalous story ! From them I had it!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (recovering something like calmness) You have not met him ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: I shall meet him !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: No, Cyril, no! you must not! I entreat, I implore you by all the tenderness we have felt for each other!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: The tenderness!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Avoid this man, Cyril! I ask it of you by your love for me!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: My love !—Woman ! is it possible you do not understand me ! I tell you, I know that this man Rashleigh has visited you this evening—that he is to repeat his visit, that you forbade your servant to speak to me on the subject; and you appeal to my love ! Strumpet! I know you at last! the mystery with which you have so carefully shrouded your past life is solved ! You have been Philip Rashleigh's mistress !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (drawing herself up proudly) Cyril!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Oh ! your airs of innocence will no longer mislead me!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (in a tone of deep pity) Poor Cyril!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: What! you have the effrontery to pity me!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes ! because I love you—with a love whose depth I scarcely knew till now !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Enough of hypocritical tears ! I am no longer to be duped by them. I—I—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Finish, Cyril—you spurn me from your house ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (with bitter irony) Doubtless, another is ready to receive you? But, before you rejoin your quondam lover, tell me by what name he called you, for you affected to be nameless when I first saw you. (she weeps silently) The name I gave you was my mother's—may she forgive me for having so profaned it. I strip it from you, and forbid you to bear it an hour—a moment longer.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (slowly going towards D. L.) Adieu, Cyril!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: What does it matter ? You have driven me from your house. (going.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Dora! (hurrying to her) Oh, why have you deceived me ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I deceived you, Cyril?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Tell me. Dora, tell me!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I can tell you nothing.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Nothing ! (endeavouring to pass him.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Then you shall not leave the house ! I will keep you here till he comes to fetch you—for he said he would return—and then I will force him to tell me all he knows of you!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Cyril, I have given you all that was mine to give in this world—my life, my love, my hope—for my only hope of peace was in the death I turned from for your sake ! In return for all I gave you, I asked but one thing —I besought you not to seek to know who I am, and you promised me.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: A rash, senseless promise, which I cannot keep !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And yet, only to-day, you renewed it.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Since then you have deceived me! and that wrong cancels all obligation. You received Philip Rashleigh here, did you not ?
Grace It is true.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: And instructed your servant to keep the fact from me ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Well, then!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You drive me from your house, Cyril; do I complain?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: But if you have not deceived me, for what purpose did Philip Rashleigh visit you? (Grace is silent) You do not answer me. What did he say to you ? what did he ask of you ? with what object is he going to repeat his visit ?—Still you do not speak !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Farewell, Cyril! (going.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Go, then—since you will have it so ! he is waiting for you, perhaps! and may you not escape the punishment you deserve, for having broken a heart that loved you so deeply as mine ! (He throws himself on to a chair, covers his face with his hands and weeps passionately.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (hesitating) Poor Cyril !—but if I stay, to-morrow will renew the misery of to-night!—No, I will not stay. (she opens the door.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (starting from his seat, and rushing to her) Dora! Dora! do not leave me! I may forgive you ! However great your fault has been, 1 will struggle to forget it. I did not say I drove you from your home—or if I did I was mad, Dora! Oh, I love you so greatly—and my suffering is so hard to bear!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Your sufferings, Cyril, are not half so hard to bear as mine.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Oh, then, why will you not with a word remove the suspicion that tortures me and makes me torture you ? Tell me that I have deceived myself ! tell me that you truly love me ! Oh ! tell me this, Dora !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Heaven only knows how I love you, Cyril.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: And yet you doubt my love !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Doubt your love ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Yes.—Dora, if I were at this moment to tell you that I have to reproach myself with a great fault—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You, Cyril ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: If I were to confess to you that, in a moment of thoughtlessness, or recklessness, I had committed a crime —

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Cyril?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: After such an avowal, would you still love me ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: A crime ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Speak! would you still love me ?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (aside) A crime ! (aloud) Cyril, what if I were to make such—such an avowal to you?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Dora!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: That—that I had committed a—a murder ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: That I was a thief?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (staggering with terror) Great heaven!—can that be?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You think it possible! (going.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Stay! my reason loses itself in a bewildering maze ! I know only that I owe my life to you— that I have loved you with all the ardour of my soul! Whatever may have been your crime, I will not abandon you—you shall not leave the shelter of my roof. Stay—till to-morrow— till I have thought of what is best for your future —

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (wildly) He believes me guilty ! Why did I let him come between me and death ! (she rushes to the sofa, seizes the stiletto, and raises it.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (rushing to her and seizing her hand) In heaven's name, Dora, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (struggling to free her hand) Die !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You shall not—you shall not! Help! help!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (still struggling) If you have any mercy for me, let me die—let me die !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p:
(wresting the stiletto from her, and throwing it away from him) You shall not, Dora—you shall not! (she utters a despairing cry, and falls senseless. Maguilp and Mrs.
Maguilp rush in from D. L., Susan from D. F. L. C. EdgeWorth sinks into a chair, while the others partially raise Grace) Heaven have pity on her and on me !

sp.speaker: Maguilp.
sp.p: (to Mrs. Maguilp) Don't say anything, but help her into the next room, (they raise Grace, and carry her out at D. F. L. C.)

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (rising, and walking to and fro) The perplexity of this horrible mystery benumbs my brain ! Like a blind man on strange ground, I stumble and lose myself whichever way I turn. Oh, who can give mo the answer to this dark enigma ? To question her further is to kill her ; yet, what can I do ? Guilty of crime I cannot believe her—in all things so gentle, so good !
sp.stage: Enter Merriton, D. L., speaking.

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: If he is alone. I will make bold— (seeing Edgeworth) Quite alone—that's all right, (going to D. L.) Come in, ladies.
sp.stage: Enter Constance and Lady Slowburn, D. L.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Lady Midford and Lady Slowburn !

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: Being both extremely anxious to see you, Mr. Edgeworth, they prevailed on me to escort them.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Pray, no apologies; but permit me to enquire to what I may attribute the honour of such a visit?

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: You will not be surprised, I am sure, when you learn the object of it.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (about to hand the chairs) Will you be kind enough to inform me

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Do not trouble yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: A few minutes after you left our house this evening. Lord Midford hastily left home; you can, perhaps, tell us where he went?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: I have no notion, madam.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Indeed ? (producing a letter) You are, perhaps, equally ignorant on the subject of this letter ?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (surprised) This letter, madam !

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (handing it) Read it. sir.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (reads) "The bearer of this note has discovered who Mrs. Edgeworth is." (he starts, and looks eagerly to the end of the letter.)

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: There's no signature to it.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (reading) "And wishes to confide this knowledge to Mr. Merriton." To Mr. Merriton !

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: Read on.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p:
(reading) "As the intimate friend of Lord Midford, Mr. Merriton will be glad to receive the intelligence
referred to, which is in the highest degree important to his lordship." (to Constance) To you, madam ?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: On that account I at once handed this note to Lord Midford.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Who, as soon as he read it. hurriedly left home, and I can find no trace of him. After the revelations of this note—as to the intimacy which apparently exists between Lord Midford and the person named —

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Mrs. Edgeworth, madam ?

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: If she is Mrs. Edgeworth—I have no hesitation in coming to you for information on the subject of Lord Midford's disappearance.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: To me, madam !

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: To you or Mrs. Edgeworth. You have the right to question her.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Question her ? No, madam—I was wrong to read this letter.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Mr. Edgeworth, my anxiety on Lord Midford's account is far too great to permit me to stand upon ceremonies. He may have been the victim of a crime.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: A crime ! (aside) Can it be possible the crime she spoke of was this? Yesterday the name of Merriton filled her with agitation! (aloud to Merriton) You know who my wife is?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: You know her I say ! In heaven's name, tell me who she is! (seizing him by the hand and drawing him to D. F. L. C.) Recognise her, and tell me whether I am to save her or give her into the hands of justice ? (throwing the portiere, aside.)

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: (starting back) Heaven have mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Who is she?

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: Grace Holden !

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (almost shrieking) Grace Holden!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (wildly) Who is Grace Holden?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (appearing at D.F. L. C.) Who calls me? Who calls Grace Holden? (seeing Merriton and the Ladies, she utters a shriek, and rushes to Edgeworth for protection) Oh, save me—save me, Cyril!
sp.stage: Mr. and Mrs. Maguilp come from D. f. L. C.

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Grace Holden! what is this name—and who are your

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You, too, Cyril! Oh, no—no—no! Tell me that I am out of my senses—that there is no one here but yourself and me, Cyril !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: No, there are others here.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (surprised, but without any increase of terror) Mr. Merriton!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: And besides——

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Lady Slowburn and her daughter,—true; the hour has come at length ! Heaven's will be done !

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: (aside) This fearful resignation—oh! what does it mean ? (aloud) Grace Holden,—I implore you to tell me what crime attaches to that name!

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: I sincerely pity you, Mr. Edgeworth,—but the crime is of too dark a character to be left unpunished.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Cyril! Cyril!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: Speak ! is this true?--Silent! Guilty ! (Grace utters a cry and falls on her knees, hiding her face in her hands.
sp.stage: Enter Lord Midford, D. L.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: (rushing to him) Arthur !

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Hush! hush, dear ! you shall know all presently, (aside, seeing Grace) She is here!

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Let this unhappy woman escape! since you are safe,—whatever her guilt may have been—I cannot bear the thought of causing her destruction.
sp.stage: Enter Rashleigh, hurriedly, D. L.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I have no such hesitation,—and therefore, at once, accuse this woman of being the murderer of my unfortunate aunt!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: A murderer!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: He!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A little less familiarity, my lord, if you please,— and no indignant sentiment.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: Philip Rashleigh,—do you know where I have just come from? Wait! (to Grace) Grace—on the night of Lady Belfield's murder, a will was stolen by the person who committed the deed.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (aside) Oh ! my father!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Who destroyed it—if there ever was one!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (aside) Cyril believes me guilty ! Let me end my misery ! (aloud) I stole the will—and destroyed it.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: (triumphantly) Now, cousin,—scoundrel in your teeth! You have all heard this wretched woman's confession!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: But all have not yet heard her motive for so accusing herself; this was, to save the man whom she believed to be her father.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Believe ! Oh ! my lord,—what do you mean ? For pity's sake ! If that unhappy man were not my father

sp.speaker: Lady S.
sp.p: Holden not her father!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: There must be no "ifs" and "beliefs" here; I call on all present to bear witness tbat she has distinctly admitted having stolen and destroyed my aunt's will!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: The will which made her the heiress to one half of Lady Belfield's great wealth !

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: (starting) How did you come to know that?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (after speaking in a whisper to Maguilp, who goes out hastily, L. D.) Because (drawing paper from, his pocket) I here hold in my hand the stolen will!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: It's a forgery !

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: The Jew of whom I bought it knew its value better as a security, Philip Rashleigh.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This is that hound Redway's doing ! Good-night! the sooner I settle accounts with him—(Maguilp returns with two Policemen, D. L.) What does this mean ?

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: It means that—if justice does not gravely miscarry, you will answer to it for the life of Lady Belfield.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: If my life is spared, cousin Midford,—it will be for a day of reckoning between us for to-night's work, take my word for it! (exit between the Policemen D.L.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh ! my lord,—for heaven's sake tell me what all this dream-like business means.

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (taking a letter from out of the will) Read his letter, Grace—it was folded in the will.

sp.speaker: Merri.
sp.p: I placed it there myself, by direction of my poor friend, Lady Belfield, on the night of her death.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (after reading the letter, repeats the last words) "Farewell, my beloved daughter— (lowering her voice, and with deep emotion) keep my sad secret, and forgive me." (aloud, placing the letter in her bosom) Forgive her !—my dear, lost mother!

sp.speaker: Lord M.
sp.p: (in a low tone to her) Sister !

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh, may heaven bless you for this moment's happiness! too great for me bear alone! — Brother ! Cyril! —husband!

sp.speaker: Edge.
sp.p: I dare not raise my eyes to you, Dora! Hate me — spurn me ! I have forfeited your love! An angel was sent me from heaven, and I was blind to the radiance of her presence! Leave me to the darkness in which I am alone worthy to live.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: On earth, Cyril, there is no light for me but that which comes love-laden from your eyes, (she stands within the flood of moonlight, and they embrace passionately.)

div.stage: (Tableau. —Constance and Lord Midford embrace; Merriton and Lady SlowbUrn appear to congratulate one another. Maguilp after embracing Mrs. Maguilp is leading her towards the door L., when he is met, face to face, by Mrs. Gibbs radiant with satisfaction, who fills the doorway.
